name: cyberchef
title: CyberChef
description: The Cyber Swiss Army Knife - a web app for encryption, encoding, compression and data analysis
author: mblode

commands.name: search
commands.title: Search CyberChef
commands.description: Search CyberChef

commands.name: to-base64
commands.title: Encode Base64
commands.description: Base64 is a notation for encoding arbitrary byte data using a restricted set of symbols that can be conveniently used by humans and processed by computers. This operation encodes raw data into an ASCII Base64 string. e.g. hello becomes aGVsbG8=

commands.name: from-base64
commands.title: Decode Base64
commands.description: Base64 is a notation for encoding arbitrary byte data using a restricted set of symbols that can be conveniently used by humans and processed by computers. This operation decodes data from an ASCII Base64 string back into its raw format. e.g. aGVsbG8= becomes hello

commands.name: csv-to-json
commands.title: CSV to JSON
commands.description: Converts a CSV file to JSON format.

commands.name: json-to-csv
commands.title: JSON to CSV
commands.description: Converts JSON data to a CSV based on the definition in RFC 4180.

commands.name: jwt-decode
commands.title: Decode JWT
commands.description: Decodes a JSON Web Token without checking whether the provided secret / private key is valid. Use 'JWT Verify' to check if the signature is valid as well.

commands.name: url-encode
commands.title: Encode URL
commands.description: Encodes problematic characters into percent-encoding, a format supported by URIs/URLs. e.g. = becomes %3d

commands.name: url-decode
commands.title: Decode URL
commands.description: Converts URI/URL percent-encoded characters back to their raw values. e.g. %3d becomes =

commands.name: generate-uuid
commands.title: Generate UUID
commands.description: Generates an RFC 4122 version 4 compliant Universally Unique Identifier (UUID), also known as a Globally Unique Identifier (GUID). A version 4 UUID relies on random numbers, in this case generated using window.crypto if available and falling back to Math.random if not.

commands.name: generate-qr-code
commands.title: Generate QR Code
commands.description: Generates a Quick Response (QR) code from the input text. A QR code is a type of matrix barcode (or two-dimensional barcode) first designed in 1994 for the automotive industry in Japan. A barcode is a machine-readable optical label that contains information about the item to which it is attached.

commands.name: generate-lorem-ipsum
commands.title: Generate Lorem Ipsum
commands.description: Generate varying length lorem ipsum placeholder text.

commands.name: convert-area
commands.title: Convert Area
commands.description: Converts a unit of area to another format.

commands.name: convert-mass
commands.title: Convert Mass
commands.description: Converts a unit of mass to another format.

commands.name: parse-color-code
commands.title: Parse Color Code
commands.description: Converts a color code in a standard format to other standard formats and displays the color itself. Example inputs: #d9edf7 or rgba(217,237,247,1) or hsla(200,65%,91%,1) or cmyk(0.12, 0.04, 0.00, 0.03)

commands.name: unescape-string
commands.title: Unescape String
commands.description: Unescapes characters in a string that have been escaped. For example, Don\'t stop me now becomes Don't stop me now.

commands.name: escape-string
commands.title: Escape String
commands.description: Escapes special characters in a string so that they do not cause conflicts. For example, Don't stop me now becomes Don\'t stop me now.

commands.name: pseudo
commands.title: Pseudo-Random Number Generator
commands.description: A cryptographically-secure pseudo-random number generator (PRNG). This operation uses the browser's built-in crypto.getRandomValues() method if available. If this cannot be found, it falls back to a Fortuna-based PRNG algorithm.

commands.name: convert-speed
commands.title: Convert Speed
commands.description: Converts a unit of speed to another format.

commands.name: convert-distance
commands.title: Convert Distance
commands.description: Converts a unit of distance to another format.

commands.name: to-upper-case
commands.title: To Upper Case
commands.description: Converts the input string to upper case, optionally limiting scope to only the first character in each word, sentence or paragraph.

commands.name: regular-expression
commands.title: Regular Expression
commands.description: Define your own regular expression (regex) to search the input data with, optionally choosing from a list of pre-defined patterns. Supports extended regex syntax including the 'dot matches all' flag, named capture groups, full unicode coverage (including \p{} categories and scripts as well as astral codes) and recursive matching.

commands.name: find-replace
commands.title: Find/Replace
commands.description: Replaces all occurrences of the first string with the second. Includes support for regular expressions (regex), simple strings and extended strings (which support \n, \r, \t, \b, \f and escaped hex bytes using \x notation, e.g. \x00 for a null byte).

commands.name: pad-lines
commands.title: Pad Lines
commands.description: Add the specified number of the specified character to the beginning or end of each line

commands.name: sort
commands.title: Sort Strings
commands.description: Alphabetically sorts strings separated by the specified delimiter.

commands.name: count-occurrences
commands.title: Count Occurrences
commands.description: Counts the number of times the provided string occurs in the input.

commands.name: unique
commands.title: Unique Strings
commands.description: Removes duplicate strings from the input.

commands.name: tail
commands.title: Tail
commands.description: Like the UNIX tail utility. Gets the last n lines. Optionally you can select all lines after line n by entering a negative value for n. The delimiter can be changed so that instead of lines, fields (i.e. commas) are selected instead.

commands.name: head
commands.title: Head
commands.description: Like the UNIX head utility. Gets the first n lines. You can select all but the last n lines by entering a negative value for n. The delimiter can be changed so that instead of lines, fields (i.e. commas) are selected instead.

commands.name: split
commands.title: Split Strings
commands.description: Splits a string into sections around a given delimiter.

commands.name: shuffle
commands.title: Shuffle Strings
commands.description: Randomly reorders input elements.

commands.name: reverse
commands.title: Reverse Strings
commands.description: Reverses the input string.

commands.name: to-table
commands.title: To Table
commands.description: Data can be split on different characters and rendered as an HTML, ASCII or Markdown table with an optional header row. Supports the CSV (Comma Separated Values) file format by default. Change the cell delimiter argument to 	 to support TSV (Tab Separated Values) or | for PSV (Pipe Separated Values). You can enter as many delimiters as you like. Each character will be treat as a separate possible delimiter.

commands.name: add-line-numbers
commands.title: Add Line Numbers
commands.description: Adds line numbers to the output.

commands.name: remove-line-numbers
commands.title: Remove Line Numbers
commands.description: Removes line numbers from the output if they can be trivially detected.

commands.name: swap-case
commands.title: Swap Case
commands.description: Converts uppercase letters to lowercase ones, and lowercase ones to uppercase ones.

commands.name: to-lower-case
commands.title: To Lower Case
commands.description: Converts every character in the input to lower case.

commands.name: remove-whitespace
commands.title: Remove Whitespace
commands.description: Optionally removes all spaces, carriage returns, line feeds, tabs and form feeds from the input data.

commands.name: translate-date-time-format
commands.title: Translate DateTime Format
commands.description: Parses a datetime string in one format and re-writes it in another.

commands.name: get-time
commands.title: Get Time
commands.description: Generates a timestamp showing the amount of time since the UNIX epoch (1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC). Uses the W3C High Resolution Time API.

commands.name: to-unix-timestamp
commands.title: To UNIX Timestamp
commands.description: Parses a datetime string in UTC and returns the corresponding UNIX timestamp. e.g. Mon 1 January 2001 11:00:00 becomes 978346800. A UNIX timestamp is a 32-bit value representing the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC (the UNIX epoch).

commands.name: from-unix-timestamp
commands.title: From UNIX Timestamp
commands.description: Converts a UNIX timestamp to a datetime string. e.g. 978346800 becomes Mon 1 January 2001 11:00:00 UTC. A UNIX timestamp is a 32-bit value representing the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC (the UNIX epoch).

commands.name: parse-date-time
commands.title: Parse DateTime
commands.description: Parses a DateTime string in your specified format and displays it in whichever timezone you choose

commands.name: extract-file-paths
commands.title: Extract File Paths
commands.description: Extracts anything that looks like a Windows or UNIX file path.

commands.name: extract-dates
commands.title: Extract Dates
commands.description: Extracts dates in the following formats: yyyy-mm-dd or dd/mm/yyyy or mm/dd/yyyy. Dividers can be any of /, -, . or space

commands.name: extract-email-addresses
commands.title: Extract Email Addresses
commands.description: Extracts all email addresses from the input.

commands.name: extract-domains
commands.title: Extract Domains
commands.description: Extracts fully qualified domain names. Note that this will not include paths. Use Extract URLs to find entire URLs.

commands.name: extract-ip-addresses
commands.title: Extract IP Addresses
commands.description: Extracts all IPv4 and IPv6 addresses.

commands.name: generic-code-beautify
commands.title: Generic Code Beautify
commands.description: Attempts to pretty print C-style languages such as C, C++, C#, Java, PHP, JavaScript etc.

commands.name: md5
commands.title: MD5 Hash
commands.description: MD5 (Message-Digest 5) is a widely used hash function. It has been used in a variety of security applications and is also commonly used to check the integrity of files.

commands.name: syntax-highlighter
commands.title: Syntax Highlighter
commands.description: Adds syntax highlighting to a range of source code languages. Note that this will not indent the code. Use one of the 'Beautify' operations for that.

commands.name: render-markdown
commands.title: Render Markdown
commands.description: Renders input Markdown as HTML. HTML rendering is disabled to avoid XSS.

commands.name: javascript-minify
commands.title: Minify JavaScript
commands.description: Compresses JavaScript code.

commands.name: javascript-beautify
commands.title: Beautify JavaScript
commands.description: Parses and pretty prints valid JavaScript code. Also works with JavaScript Object Notation (JSON).

commands.name: json-beautify
commands.title: Beautify JSON
commands.description: Indents and pretty prints JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) code.

commands.name: json-minify
commands.title: Minify JSON
commands.description: Compresses JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) code.

commands.name: sql-beautify
commands.title: Beautify SQL
commands.description: Indents and prettifies Structured Query Language (SQL) code.

commands.name: css-beautify
commands.title: Beautify CSS
commands.description: Indents and prettifies Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) code.

commands.name: css-minify
commands.title: Minify CSS
commands.description: Compresses Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) code.

commands.name: diff
commands.title: Diff Inputs
commands.description: Compares two inputs (separated by the specified delimiter) and highlights the differences between them.

commands.name: to-snake-case
commands.title: To Snake Case
commands.description: Converts the input string to snake case. Snake case is all lower case with underscores as word boundaries. e.g. this_is_snake_case

commands.name: to-kebab-case
commands.title: To Kebab Case
commands.description: Converts the input string to kebab case. Kebab case is all lower case with dashes as word boundaries. e.g. this-is-kebab-case

commands.name: to-camel-case
commands.title: To Camel Case
commands.description: Converts the input string to camel case. Camel case is all lower case except letters after word boundaries which are uppercase. e.g. thisIsCamelCase

preferences.description: Enter the URL of the CyberChef instance you want to use. Defaults to the official instance.
preferences.name: cyberChefUrl
preferences.title: CyberChef Instance URL
